timeline.summary: The document is a series of email exchanges between law enforcement (NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force) and an Assistant United States Attorney regarding the investigation of Jeffrey Epstein.  The investigation involves reviewing 911 calls originating from Epstein’s alarm company, searching DAS databases for relevant information, and tracking Epstein’s phone number.  The communications include requests for sprint reports, DAS searches, and the review of SOMU records. Several individuals and locations are redacted.

*   Multiple individuals (identified only as “[REDACTED]”) within the NYPD, FBI, and the Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force are involved in an investigation related to "Epstein." *   The investigation centers around 911 calls originating from an alarm company and a DAS search yielding information about an employee and property manager associated with 9 E 71 Street. *   A phone number (212-533-3739) linked to Epstein is being investigated via DAS searches. *   Requests are being made to obtain sprint reports related to the 911 calls and to subpoena NYPD communications. *   One individual advises another to change their name. *   The communication occurred on December 10, 2018, with discussions planned for later that day and the following week.

On 2019-01-29 at 21:50:00 +0000, a meeting occurred with an individual regarding Jeffrey Epstein, categorized as “X-PERSONAL.” The organizer is unknown. The meeting lasted from 21:50:00 to 22:00:00 +0000, was created on 2019-01-29 21:09:00 +0000, and modified at the same time. It had a priority of 5 and a DTSTAMP of 2019-01-29 20:56:58 +0000. A reminder was set to display a message 15 minutes before the start.

The logs detail various activities within the NYM SHU and Housing Unit, Special (SHU) – specifically Level 1 (SHU), Level 2 (SHU), and Level 3 (9 SOUTH SHU).  These entries include shift changes, official counts, routine checks (body alarms, fire panels, inventory, keys, OC spray, radios), searches of areas, rounds by officers and lieutenants, and the feeding of inmates. Multiple users (TF59463, TF18923, TF18830, TF49363, TF18945, TF28247 and TF34228) logged these activities.

Counts varied between 789 and 792 inmates. SHU (Special Housing Unit) placements and movements were frequent, with inmates being moved between units and hospitals. There were several instances of inmates placed in administrative detention due to issues such as cell phone possession or refusal to obey orders. Telephone monitoring included WITSEC inquiries and STG/High Alert calls, though no alerts were triggered during the shifts. Restraint equipment was inventoried regularly, and metal detector checks were conducted. System malfunctions impacted the Public Address System. Visitation occurred on June 27th.

There were system malfunctions impacting the Public Address System. Shifts were divided into Morning Watch, Day Watch, and Evening Watch, with consistent counts and observations recorded throughout each shift.

On July 2, 2019, a Metropolitan Correctional Center Lieutenant documented daily operations, including counts, inmate observations (psychological observations, administrative detentions), equipment checks, and security procedures.  Counts were conducted at 12:00 AM, 3:00 AM, 5:00 AM, 6:00 AM, and 10:00 AM.  Various inmate movements occurred, including transfers, returns, and administrative detentions.  Phone calls were monitored, including WITSEC inquiries.  The shift involved responding to alarms, conducting trash runs, and managing visitation. The counts varied throughout the shift, starting at 796, decreasing to 783, and then increasing to 788 before the shift ended.

The Lieutenant’s shift involved managing inmate movement, responding to system malfunctions, conducting trash runs, and overseeing visitation. Counts were conducted at 12:00 AM, 3:00 AM, 5:00 AM, and 8:00 AM.  The SHU (Special Housing Unit) status was consistently 73/5.  There were no reported incidents of inmates being transferred to or from the hospital.

This document is a daily log from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, documenting the activities of a lieutenant overseeing a shift. The log records counts, inmate movements (including transfers to hospital and administrative detention), equipment checks (metal detectors, restraint equipment), and responses to alarms and phone calls. The log also records routine tasks like trash runs and provides inmate visitation statistics. The shift covers three days: July 6th, July 7th, and July 5th, with counts recorded at various times throughout each day.

On July 6th and 7th, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York documented daily operations led by a Lieutenant. There were several institutional counts throughout the shifts, along with body alarm testing, NYPD phone checks, and trash runs. The counts varied between 787 and 789, and SHU status and unit assignments were consistently recorded. Visitation records were also maintained.

Several inmates were moved between units, including one transported to a local hospital. There were several instances of phone calls monitored, including STG and High Alert calls, and WITSEC inquiries.  Administrative detentions were recorded for inmates #50972-054 and #76318-054, with reasons and times documented.  The log details system malfunctions (fire alarm, PA system), trash runs, and standard operational procedures.  The final count at the end of each shift was recorded.

On July 13, 2019, a correctional officer’s daily log documented operations at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. This document is a daily log of a Lieutenant’s shift at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, covering Saturday, July 13, 2019. The log details routine activities including counts, inventory checks, security procedures (metal detectors, alarm testing), inmate observations (psychological, suicide watch), and administrative actions (detentions, furloughs). There were multiple inmate counts throughout the day, disruptions due to system malfunctions, and monitoring of STG and High Alert phone calls. A notable event was a furlough to a Housing Area (HA) and a temporary chit inventory was conducted. The log records the shift change and the final count of 798 inmates.

Lieutenant’s shifts involved managing inmate activities, conducting counts, responding to alarms, and addressing issues like sprinkler malfunctions and bed space shortages. There were several inmate placements in administrative detention and ongoing monitoring of STG/High Alert phone calls and WITSEC inquiries. The counts varied throughout the day, with a final count of 799 recorded at the end of the shift.

*   **Starting Counts:** The initial counts throughout the shifts varied between 796 and 799 inmates. *   **SHU Status:** The Special Housing Unit (SHU) contained approximately 78 inmates, with fluctuating numbers due to administrative detentions and movements. *   **Daily Activities:** The log detailed routine activities including counts, inventory checks, restraint equipment management, fire alarm testing, phone calls (including STG/High Alert monitoring and WITSEC inquiries), and inmate movements (e.g., to court, HA, ZA, general population). *   **Administrative Detentions:** Several inmates were placed in Administrative Detention throughout the shifts. *   **Visitation:** Visitation records noted 24 total inmates – 9 adults and 10 children. *   **Equipment Issues:** There were noted instances of system malfunctions, specifically relating to the Institution Public Address System used for PREA announcements.

Throughout the shifts, there were numerous institutional counts with varying results (798, 796, 785, 786, 787, 794, 77/5, 78/5, 76/5, 78/4, 79/5, 76/4). There were also issues with the PREA announcement system and a malfunctioning door panel.  No STG/High Alert or WITSEC phone calls were received. Visitation records were not available for this shift.

On July 22, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York documented daily operations, including counts, security checks, and inmate activity. The shift ended with a count of 776 inmates.

*   A daily activity report for July 22, 2019, was received and reviewed. *   A 911 operator reported a potential stabbing threat by the "Macballers" gang members at 11-South housing unit. *   A fire alarm and sprinkler system was inoperable, triggering a fire watch. *   Inmates were reassigned to the Special Housing Unit (SHU): Jones #87016-054, Romero #74203-054, and Williams #78640-054. *   Staffing shortages led to vacant correctional assignments. *   Pressure pump system failure initiated a fire watch. *   New inmate admissions and releases were recorded. *   Missing reports and equipment inventory forms were identified across various areas of the Metropolitan Correctional Center. *   Leave utilization and overtime hours were documented. *   The institution’s inmate count at the beginning of the morning shift was recorded.

On July 22, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) reported the following: *   A threat of a stabbing by gang members was reported by the Control Center regarding the 11-South housing unit. *   A fire alarm and sprinkler system were inoperable, triggering a fire watch. *   Inmates were temporarily relocated to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) due to staff shortages. *   A pressure pump system failure resulted in a continued fire watch. *   There were no cells triple-bunked. *   Several areas lacked missing fire and security reports and equipment inventories. *   Staff utilized overtime hours (E-1, 60-Q, B-2, O9D, XXX, 87S) and various leave types (furlough, annual, sick, suspension, etc.). *   The institution’s total inmate count at 12:00 AM was 776, distributed across various units.

On July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM, an inmate, Jeffrey Epstein (#76318-054), attempted suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. Multiple officers responded to the alarm, finding Epstein in a fetal position with a makeshift noose around his neck. He exhibited erratic behavior, including attempting to stand and falling, and made statements about his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione (#78514-054), attempting to kill him and extorting money. Tartaglione reported feeling struck by something in his bunk and witnessed Epstein with a rope. Epstein claimed he’d informed his attorney about the threats. Medical staff assessed Epstein, finding a circular erythema on his neck, and he was placed on suicide watch. The incident involved multiple officers, a medical assessment, and documentation of the events by those present.

Around 6:33 AM, a body alarm was triggered, and staff discovered him unresponsive. Medical personnel initiated CPR and other life-saving measures, eventually intubating him and transporting him to Beekman Hospital. He was pronounced dead at 7:36 AM. The following events occurred: *   **Immediate Response (August 9):**  Initial calls to emergency services, USMS, SIS, FBI, and various institutional staff (Warden, Psychologist, Captain, etc.) were made. Reyes, Epstein’s cellmate, was released from court and did not return to the institution. *   **Investigation (August 9-11):**  Investigators, including the FBI, OIG, medical examiners, and computer services personnel, conducted interviews, took fingerprints and photographs, secured clothing, and removed computers from Epstein’s cell. The Medical Examiner performed an autopsy, and a press release was issued. *   **Evidence Collection (August 10-11):**  The OIG and FBI collected computer evidence (two FPS computers), and the Computer Services Manager replaced the seized computers. The timeline concluded with the removal of the computers and the departure of OIG/FBI personnel from the MCC New York.

Jeffrey Epstein’s death occurred on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The timeline begins with his court appearance at 8:30 am, followed by a social call at 7:00 pm. At 6:33 am on August 10th, a body alarm was triggered, and Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell. Medical personnel initiated CPR and provided interventions before transporting him to Beekman Hospital. Despite efforts, he was pronounced dead at 7:36 am. A series of agencies, including US Marshals, FBI, Bureau of Prisons, and the Office of the Inspector General (OIG), responded to the scene and conducted investigations, including interviews, forensic examinations (fingerprints, photographs, autopsy), and the removal of electronic devices. The investigation continued into the following day, with OIG and FBI agents collecting evidence and computers before departing the institution.

This document is a series of fax records detailing household maintenance and security services provided to Jeffrey Epstein’s residences (Epstein House and a staff house). The records cover the period from September 2003 to August 2005, documenting the hours worked by various contractors and staff, including cleaners, gardeners, security personnel, and repair technicians.  Specific tasks included cleaning, landscaping, alarm system management, grocery shopping, car maintenance, and general household upkeep. The records also track payments made to these individuals/companies, totaling approximately $990.00 in 2003 and increasing to around $3,000.00 by 2005. Recurring contractors like Peadon’s Cleaning and Lenny were frequently utilized.  The records include detailed instructions regarding alarm codes, passwords, and specific tasks requested by Epstein. There are mentions of specific individuals like Richard, Christopher, and Larry, and frequently referenced properties/locations like the staff house, the main house (4312), and various repair services. The final page includes a contact list for billing.
